job_history.work_description: Formulated, proposed, and was authorized to implement 'The Arts Project,' a weekly therapeutic, expressive arts program for 10+ 'at-risk' CPS middle school students residing in a low-income urban neighborhood.

Designed & delivered curriculum for weekly coping skills sessions with groups of 20-50 early adolescents & their mentors. Tailored sessions to address unique risk factors faced by our youth (e.g. community violence, chronic poverty, school dropout). Integrated therapeutic approaches from various evidence-based practices (DBT, CBT, Mindfulness-based Stress Reduction). Produced & administered usability, feasibility, and satisfaction forms for coping skills training attendees (staff, mentors, & mentees). Evaluated and amended curriculum based on youth, mentor, and staff feedback.

Developed measures and organized platforms for more than 50 mentors to report contact with mentee. Conducted thorough interviews with potential mentors, youth participants, and parents of youth in the mentoring intervention so to arrange meaningful and lasting youth-mentor relationships. Supervised up to 8 mentor-mentee pairs at a time; monitored and documented all contact & activities between pairs. Combined forces with teachers and parents regularly to assess the needs of and establish protective resources for our youth. Organized weekly meetings with each supervisee to problem-solve, provide support, and address conflicts or concerns regarding their mentoring relationship.

Over the course of 6 academic terms, promoted engaging discussions, critical thinking, and a warm learning environment for groups of 50-60 undergraduate students enrolled in PSY-305 (a community-based service learning course). Was selected out of four graduate assistants to be 'Head Teaching Assistant' of the course throughout 2013-14 academic year.

Guided individuals with developmental disabilities in achieving personal goals, overcoming barriers, & participating in activities of their choice; recorded progress on skill development and achievement. Served as a role model and mentor; demonstrated and coached social and behavioral skill development. Prompted & praised the use of independent living skills, such as cooking, money management, household shopping, doing laundry, & personal hygiene.

interests: Child Life Volunteer - Children's Memorial Hospital (2011-2012)
United Way Volunteer - Hearts of West Michigan (2009)
Animal Shelter Volunteer - Kent County Animal Shelter (2008)

skills.name: Program Development
skills.explanation: Formulated, proposed, and implemented 'The Arts Project,' a weekly therapeutic, expressive arts program, and designed & delivered curriculum for weekly coping skills sessions, demonstrating strong proficiency.

skills.name: Leadership

skills.name: Mentorship
skills.explanation: Supervised up to 8 mentor-mentee pairs at a time, monitored and documented all contact & activities between pairs, and conducted thorough interviews with potential mentors, demonstrating strong proficiency.

skills.name: Teaching

skills.explanation: Guided individuals with developmental disabilities in achieving personal goals, overcoming barriers, & participating in activities of their choice, demonstrating a solid working proficiency.

skills.name: Volunteer Management
skills.explanation: Participated in various volunteer roles, such as Child Life Volunteer, United Way Volunteer, Animal Shelter Volunteer, and Summer Camp Volunteer, showing some practical experience.

skills.name: Project Evaluation
skills.explanation: Produced & administered usability, feasibility, and satisfaction forms for coping skills training attendees, and evaluated and amended curriculum based on feedback, demonstrating a solid working proficiency.
